entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model - Introducing Release Cadence Settings
entry.content:
Dear Administrators, 

You may have already noticed some exciting additions to the Administration Settings panel over the past few months. Today, we are pleased to introduce a powerful new feature designed to give you more flexibility and control over how updates for SAP Profitability and Performance Management - Standard Model are delivered to you: Fast Track mode. 

What is Fast Track Mode? 

Have you ever wished you could access the latest SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud - Standard Model (referred to as SAP PaPM Cloud SM hereon) features earlier ‚Äî before they are rolled out globally across all tenants? 

With Fast Track Mode, this is now possible. 

By simply activating the Fast Track mode toggle in the Administration Settings, your selected tenant will immediately begin receiving more frequent updates for SAP PaPM Cloud SM. This includes early access to new functionalities and improvements‚Äîideal for your development and quality assurance environments where early testing is beneficial. 

 

What‚Äôs the Default Behavior? 

By default, Fast Track Mode is deactivated, meaning your tenant will receive updates of SAP PaPM Cloud SM only once per month, specifically on the second Monday of the month. So, the default release cadence for such updates is monthly.

However, the same updates become available a few weeks earlier for tenants where Fast Track mode is activated. This provides a valuable window to test changes in advance and ensure everything is working perfectly with your specific business scenarios. 

Note: Given that we are gradually rolling this feature out across all regions, latest by 1 Nov 2025 all the tenants will be moved to the default release cadence - meaning, Fast Track mode will be in deactivated state for everyone. Administrators will have the option to activate Fast Track mode for themselves using the toggle as described earlier.


How to Activate or Deactivate Fast Track Mode? 

Activating Fast Track mode is straightforward: 

  • Navigate to Administration Settings.

  • Activate the Fast Track mode toggle. 

The change takes effect immediately. 

Need to revert to the default release cadence? No problem. Simply switch off the toggle. Please note that reverting may require waiting until the next monthly release (i.e., next month). 

We hope this new option helps you make the most of your multiple SAP PaPM Cloud SM tenants. Stay tuned‚Äîmore updates and tips are coming your way!

entry.title: How to increase the number of valid values of a combo box from default 100
entry.content:
Hello,
 
I am doing a SAP B1 web client extensibility project using UI API extensions (VSCode) in which on a UDO form , I am adding a custom grid.One of the column in the custom grid is of type combo box.
I am filling this combobox using a field from another UDO. The problem I am facing is that even if the service layer response gets back around 316 records from that UDO,
The combobox only shows 100 records listed.So I am not able to select other values.
 
How can I increase the number of valid values in that combo box.My combo filling code is given below. Also the layout file setting of the combocontrol is given. Can anybody help?
I tried setSizeLimit() for the datamodel,It is not allowed in web client UI API.
 
************* Combo filling code*********************************
 
 async POLineFill(oEnv) {
      try {
        console.log("POLineFill started");
        const oView = await oEnv.ActiveView();
        
        await oView.setCustomizedData(null, "data3");
 
        const service = await oEnv.getService();
        let response = await service.ServiceLayer.get("TWBS_CM_CONT?$select=U_POLine");
        
        if(!response.isSuccess()){
          console.log("Service call failed in POLineFill");
          return;
        }
 
        let podata = response.getData();
        let allItems = new Map();
        console.log(`Fetched ${podata.value.length} POLines from first page`);
 
        // Add empty option
        allItems.set("", { key: "", text: "", id: "empty-option" });
 
        // Process initial data
        podata.value.forEach((item, index) => {
          if (item.U_POLine) {
            allItems.set(item.U_POLine, {
              key: item.U_POLine,
              text: item.U_POLine,
              id: `poline-${index}`
            });
          }
        });
 
        // Handle pagination
        let nextUrl = podata['@odata.nextLink'];
        let pageIndex = 1;
        console.log("Next url  for pagination:", nextUrl);
 
        while (nextUrl) {
          let nextResponse = await service.ServiceLayer.get(nextUrl);
          if (!nextResponse.isSuccess()) break;
          
          let nextData = nextResponse.getData();
          
          nextData.value.forEach((item, index) => {
            if (item.U_POLine && !allItems.has(item.U_POLine)) {
              allItems.set(item.U_POLine, {
                key: item.U_POLine,
                text: item.U_POLine,
                id: `poline-${pageIndex}-${index}`
              });
            }
          });
          console.log(`Fetched ${nextData.value.length} POLines from page ${pageIndex + 1}`);
          nextUrl = nextData['@odata.nextLink'];
          pageIndex++;
        }
 
        // Convert to array
        const comboBoxData = Array.from(allItems.values()).sort();
 
        console.log(`Total unique POLines loaded: ${comboBoxData.length}`);
 
        await oView.setCustomizedData({ comboBoxData }, "data3");
        
        
        console.log("POLineFill completed");
        
      } catch(error) {
        console.error("Error in POLineFill:", error);
      }
    }
 
************   layout file***********************************
 
                                             "columns": [
 
{
"ctrlType": "b1.sdk.Column",

entry.title: Re: ATP in Sales Orders no longer considers QI stock with EWM
entry.content:
Hi,

we have upgraded our system to S/4HANA 2023 and have discovered the same problema.

In S/4HANA 2020 this worked perfectly and the inspection lots 17* from EWM were seen and proessed correctly in the ATP.

Since the upgrade it seems that this is not working anymore.

The problema seems to be related to the inspection lot rather than to the wuality stock because we have checked this scenarios:
-Stock in Q in EWM with inspection lot 17 --> NOT IN ATP.
-Stock in Q in MM with inspection lot 01 --> OK IN ATP.
-Stock in FREE in EWM --> OK IN ATP.
-Stock in FREE in MM --> OK IN ATP.
-Stock in Q in EWM with inspection lot 17 that as been sent to MM and then back to EWM --> OK IN ATP.

The last case works, because it loses the reference to the inspection lot.

The ATP scope has the Q stock checked so ti should be taken into account even if it is in a 17 inspection lot.

Hoping that someone knows the answer...

Best regards.

entry.title: SAP TechEd2025-XP264- Explore how to run cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Kyma runtime
entry.content:
Description

A sneak preview of the material for the SAP TechEd 2025 session catalog number XP264 - Explore how to run cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Kyma runtime.

  • Day-2 Operations: Management, Maintenance, Monitoring, and Optimization
  • Technical connectivity to public and private (on-premise) systems

The repository with the session material will be available publicly on Monday, November 3rd.

 

Overview

This session introduces attendees to Day-2 operations with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime - a managed kubernetes environment to help connect and extend enterprise applications in the cloud-native world.

In a nutshell, SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime (SKR) is a managed offering of a Kubernetes Cluster based on Gardener, extended by a set of building blocks called Kyma modules.
The idea being that each instance of SAP BTP Kyma runtime environment is a separate Kubernetes cluster with its own set of modules.
All these clusters are managed by a central Kyma Control Plane (KCP) that orchestrates the lifecycle of

  • the underlying hyperscaler project,
  • the Gardener Cluster,
  • and the Kyma modules.

 

 

During the session you will learn

  • how to operate applications with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime and discover the power of smooth integration with cloud applications and on-premise systems using the advanced connectivity features.
  • to explore operational best practices from mastering troubleshooting techniques and intelligent root-cause analysis to event-driven autoscaling that adapts to your business needs in real time.
  • about BTP multitenant applications with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime.

Requirements

The requirements to follow the exercises in this repository are...

Important

  • You must be able to fork the repository and activate the github actions at the fork. This is mandatory for this session!
  • Thus, you may need a GitHub user.
    If you haven't got one yet, please sign-up on GitHub before the workshop or at the very beginning of the session.

Important

The session content is provided exclusively on the SAP-Samples github, and many excercises have been implemented as CI/CD Github Actions worflows (GHA).

Tip

Security is paramount. With the Github Action IDP-delegated flow, there is no more need to provide kubernetes and btp credentials when using github actions.

  • ‚úÖThe Github Action workflows acting as the OIDC provider.

  • ‚úÖAll the kubernetets environments in the landscape are configured to trust GitHub‚Äôs token identity provider. They come with the pre-configured OIDC applications leveraging the built-in Gardener OIDC shoot extension.

  • ‚úÖSAP Cloud Identity Services acting as a platform IDP on the BTP side of the house has been federated with the Github actions OIDC Provider

  • ‚úÖAs a result, the very short-lived credentials are being fetched and rotated automatically on the behalf of the repository user for both kubernetes and btp platform operations.

  • The good news is you may run the GHA-based exercises directly, from your forked repository, in a browser on the provided teched laptop.

Disclaimer

Personal devices should not be used for this session.

  • üëâRun and take time to inspect the results of the built-in automations. Ask questions. And if you feel like doing, go ahead and create your own variants as well.

  • üëâThe recommendation is, however, to go with the flow of the exercises, inspect the results, ask questions and leave the rest for the homework.

  • For all other exercises which may require a terminal use, you may use the built-in VSCode terminal window.

  • As this is a Day-2 operation brief, the entire cloud landscape has been pre-configured with a number of shared components, for instance:

    • üîóSAP Cloud Identity Services (SAP IAS)
    • üîóSAP Cloud Logging
    • üîóSAP HANA Cloud
    • üîóArgoCDaaS
    • üîóSAP BTP Connectivity services - Destination service, Connectivity service, Cloud Connector, Connectivity Proxy and Transparent Proxy
    • üîóS4/HANA On-premise (private cloud) with the Cloud Connector in the private network.

  • All of the SAP Kyma environments have been configured to the same template (via terraform automation).

  • Last but not least, you will be able to play with a pre-deployed SAP Build multitenant application deployed to one of the kyma clusters.

  • üììFYI: There are several additional command line tools available on your SAP TECHED 2025 Client laptops, for instance:

    • kubectl plugin list
      The following compatible plugins are available:

C:\Software\CLI\Kubernetes\kubectl-convert.exe
C:\Users\TE-06\.krew\bin\kubectl-krew.exe
C:\Users\TE-06\.krew\bin\kubectl-oidc_login.exe
C:\Users\TE-06\.krew\bin\kubectl-resource_capacity.exe
C:\Users\TE-06\.krew\bin\kubectl-view_serviceaccount_kubeconfig.exe
       
    • jq, curl, kyma cli, terraform, etc.

Let's get started...

  • Exercise 0 - Preparation Steps

    • Exercise 0.0 - Sign up for a GitHub account
    • Exercise 0.1 - Fork the teched2025-XP264 repository
    • Exercise 0.2 - Let the session begin!
    • Exercise 0.3 - BTP landscape at a glance
    • Exercise 0.4 - Let's talk SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime architecture

  • Exercise 1 - First things first. Day-2 with SAP Kyma managed kubernetes runtime

    • Exercise 1.1 - Easy access to your session landscape (with SSO).
    • Exercise 1.2 - Built-in github automation flows
    • Exercise 1.3 - Zoom on Kyma CLI (optional)
    • Exercise 1.4 - Firefighter access
    • Exercise 1.5 - Terraforming kyma runtime environment
    • Exercise 1.6 - Multitenancy playground

  • Exercise 2 - Using External Scalers. Keda - the Kubernetes Event-driven Autoscaler.

    • Exercise 2.0 - Introduction to kubernetes autoscalers
    • Exercise 2.1 - HPA - Horizontal Pod Autoscaler
    • Exercise 2.2 - KEDA - Kubernetes Event-driven Autoscaler
    • Exercise 2.3 - KEDA - Cron based scaler

  • Exercise 3 - Explore Kyma Telemetry Features with SAP Cloud Logging

    • Exercise 3.0 - Simulate some load
    • Exercise 3.1 - Access SAP Cloud Logging
    • Exercise 3.2 - Explore Logs
    • Exercise 3.3 - Explore Metrics
    • Exercise 3.4 - Explore Traces

  • Exercise T1 - Enable Transparent Proxy Kyma Module (optional)

    • Exercise T1.1 - Navigate To The Kyma Dashboard
    • Exercise T1.2 - Enable Transparent Proxy Module
    • Exercise T1.3 - Explore What Changed In The Kyma Instance

  • Exercise T2 - Configure Transparent Proxy Kyma Module

    • Exercise T2.1 - Navigate to your working Namespace in Kyma Dashboard
    • Exercise T2.2 - Create a dynamic Destination Custom Resource
    • Exercise T2.3 - Create a static Destination Custom Resource
    • Exercise T2.4 - Explore the results of the creation of the Destination CRs via Kubectl

  • Exercise T3 - Use Transparent Proxy Kyma Module

    • Exercise T3.1 - Run a cURL Pod Included in the Istio Service Mesh
    • Exercise T3.2 - Connect to remote systems defined as destinations using the dynamic "gateway" Destination CR
    • Exercise T3.3 - Connect to a remote system defined as destination using the dedicated (static) "s4any" Destination CR

entry.title: Re: Steps to fetch data from S/4HANA into SAP Digital Man...
entry.content:
Hi @aziz_khan,
and thank you for tagging me! üòä
First of all, do you have the official integration guide? (click on the link)
It‚Äôs very clear and, based on your architecture (e.g. S/4HANA Public Cloud, Private Cloud, ECC), it outlines all the necessary steps to ensure proper communication between SAP and Digital Manufacturing.


Here‚Äôs a quick summary of the key activities required for a correct configuration (from my bad memory!):

  • SAP Cloud Connector: must be defined and configured as suggested in the guide.
  • SAP Integration Suite: needs to be set up with the SAP S/4HANA integration package.
  • SAP DM subaccount: requires configuration such as credential creation, role collections, and more.
  • SAP IS subaccount: also needs credential setup.
  • SAP DM app: the plant must be defined, and under Manage Business Settings ‚Üí Integrations, you need to configure the interfaces. Also, under Manage Collaboration Links, you can activate the necessary interfaces (e.g., posting confirmations to SAP after completing an operation).

There might be other steps I‚Äôm forgetting, but this list covers the main ones. It‚Äôs not in a specific order, but if you follow the official guide I shared (and if the link doesn‚Äôt work anymore, just search ‚ÄúSAP DM integration guide‚Äù on Google), you‚Äôll find a well-structured PDF that walks you through the integration process step by step.

Let me know if you need further support!

entry.title: Re: SAP RAP - ABAP Runtime Error 'BEHAVIOR_ILLEGAL_STATEMENT
entry.content:
This error occurs because actions in RAP run inside a transactional buffer managed by the framework.
Hence, statements like COMMIT WORK , ROLLBACK WORK, or BAPIs that perform commits (such as BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT ) are not allowed ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs a managed or unmanaged scenario.

In RAP, the framework controls the LUW (Logical Unit of Work).
If you need to call BAPIs that normally require a commit, handle the commit inside the SAVE method (not inside the action) in an unmanaged scenario.

This ensures all changes are committed only after RAP‚Äôs transactional checks are complete and prevents the runtime error BEHAVIOR_ILLEGAL_STATEMENT.

entry.title: Error during processing of Inbound Bank Message(SAP_COM_0256)
entry.content:
Hello All,

Good Day!!
I am trying to execute soap api with payment status payload(PAIN.002.001.003). But the inbound message processing is failed at BCM with below errors.

  • BCM return code (sy-subrc): 5 / Exception name: proxy_error
  • Element 'MessageHeader' missing

I have added header and proxy details in soap payload, but still facing same error..
Please help me if I am missing anything.

entry.title: Upcoming Espresso Session - Optimizing Downstream Operations with SAP SDM and RFNO
entry.content:
Join us for the upcoming Espresso Session: Optimizing Downstream Operations with SAP SDM and RFNO. This focused 25-minute session brings together SAP and one of our leading downstream partners, Implico, to show how Secondary Distribution Management (SDM) and Retail Fuel Network Operations (RFNO) can transform downstream business operations from planning through retail execution.

‚ÑπÔ∏è  What this session is about 

The session will demonstrate how SDM and RFNO integrate with native SAP processes to automate distribution planning, inventory and replenishment, retail network management, pricing, and compliance tracking. We‚Äôll also highlight recently released features and preview roadmap items that expand analytics, mobile capabilities, and automation-driven optimization.

üí°Why attend

entry.title: Obtain ATP in bulk (internal table)
entry.content:
Hi guys

I want to avoid a function within a LOOP (optimize performance). This function 'BAPI_MATERIAL_AVAILABILITY' is to obtain the ATP but of value in value. I need to take it out of the loop and pass only the call to a local method that gets me the ATP massively (by internal table).

After trying a thousand things, and losing several hours I think my best solution is the class ‚ÄòCL_ATP_CONTROLLER‚Äô with his method ‚ÄòCHECK_AVAILABILITY‚Äô. Bellow you can see the code used but always the answer is (et_atp_results = lt_atp_results) lt_atp_results-available_qty =0.  And does not get me ATP  (verified with CO09).

Can you give me your opinion or alternatives?

Thank you very much Xavi

ABAP CODE:

DATA: lt_scheduleline_success TYPE tbl_atpcs_s4,
lt_pred_ref TYPE tbl_atp_ref,
lt_delta TYPE tbl_atp_delta_pac,
lt_sched_result TYPE tbl_atp_scheduling_result,
lt_atp_results TYPE tbl_atp_results,
lo_atp_ctrl TYPE REF TO cl_atp_controller.

CREATE OBJECT lo_atp_ctrl.

lo_atp_ctrl->initialize( ).

APPEND VALUE #(
matnr = ‚Äò9134725‚Äô
werks = ‚Äò001‚Äô
sobkz = ‚Äô ‚Äô " Stock especial: B = Pedido de ventas
sskey = ‚Äô ‚Äô
sskey_ext = ‚Äô ‚Äô
lgort = ‚Äô ‚Äô
charg = ‚Äò0000000001‚Äô
berid = ‚Äò001‚Äô
base_uom = ‚ÄòUN‚Äô " Unitat de mesura
reqdate = sy-datum " Data de la necessitat
reqqty = 9999999999 " IMPORTANT: Quantitat sol¬∑licitada
mtvfp = ‚ÄòZ2‚Äô
prreg = ‚ÄòA‚Äô " Regla de verificaci√≥
trtyp = ‚ÄòA‚Äô " Tipus de transacci√≥: A = Consulta
resmd = ‚Äô ‚Äô " Gesti√≥ de recursos
enmng = 9999999999 " Quantitat en unitat base
pac_relevant = ‚ÄòX‚Äô " Rellevant per a PAC
pal_relevant = ‚Äô ‚Äô " No rellevant per a PAL
arun_relevant = ‚Äô ‚Äô " No rellevant per a ARUN
) TO lt_scheduleline_success.

CHECK lt_scheduleline_success IS NOT INITIAL.

TRY.
lo_atp_ctrl->check_availability(
EXPORTING
it_scheduleline = lt_scheduleline_success
it_pred_ref = lt_pred_ref
it_delta_correction = lt_delta
it_delta_dbstate = lt_delta "Afegim aquest par√†metre tamb√©
it_sched_result = lt_sched_result
IMPORTING
et_atp_results = lt_atp_results
et_sched_result = DATA(lt_sched_result_success)
et_exception = DATA(lt_exception_cur_iteration)
et_message = DATA(lt_message)
et_results_decision = DATA(lt_results_decision_success) ).

CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_error).
WRITE: / ‚ÄòError capturat:‚Äô, lx_error->get_text( ).
ENDTRY.

" Verifiquem els missatges d‚Äôerrors
IF lt_message IS NOT INITIAL.
" Processa els missatges d‚Äôerror aqu√≠
LOOP AT lt_message INTO DATA(ls_message).
WRITE: / ls_message-msgty, ls_message-msgid, ls_message-msgno, ls_message-msgv1.
ENDLOOP.
ENDIF.

" Verifiquem els resultats
LOOP AT lt_atp_results INTO DATA(ls_atp_result).
WRITE: / ‚ÄòQuantitat disponible:‚Äô, ls_atp_result-available_qty,
/ ‚ÄòData confirmaci√≥:‚Äô, ls_atp_result-cnfdate.
ENDLOOP.

entry.title: SAP B1 Web client UI API extensibility requirements
entry.content:
Hi ,

I am developing a SAP Business One web client UI API extension addon in which I have two requirements to do.

1. I need to show a spinner or busy indicator when a UDO detail form loads and fill the data completely so that user may not be able to do any UI clicks/operation till the data loads completely.
How can I achieve this? which control I need to use and how?
If any sample code is provided, it will be very helpful

2. When we go to the list view of objects like Sales Order, delivery and check the view settings button only the fields from "DocNum" to "Printed" is selected so that
only those fields are available in the list view to sort.
But when we create a UDO object and go to its list view, all othe fields in that UDO is showing as selected in the view settings.
Only deselecting manually is possible.Is there any way to limit the number of fields which are shown in the view settings screen as selected?
Do any way at the time of UDO creation this can be achieved programmatically?


Thanks,

Deepesh

entry.title: Re: In the maintenance order, 2nd step submit for approva...
entry.content:
You can automate the ‚ÄúSubmit for Approval‚Äù status change once the order is saved.

Enhancement Point:

  • BAdI: WORKORDER_UPDATE

  • Exit: IWO1_ORDER_SAVE

Logic:
When order is created (AUART = your order type, e.g. PM01):

  • Check if it‚Äôs newly created (OBJNR not existing in AUFK before save).

  • Automatically trigger status ‚ÄúSubmit for Approval‚Äù (custom status like ZSUB) or trigger the workflow event.

entry.title: Creating sales order through csv file as an input
entry.content:
DATA: lt_lines TYPE TABLE OF string,
lt_columns TYPE TABLE OF string,
lv_line TYPE string,
lv_file TYPE string,
lv_vbeln TYPE bapivbeln-vbeln.

DATA: ls_order_header_in TYPE bapisdhd1,
ls_order_header_inx TYPE bapisdhd1x,
lt_order_items_in TYPE TABLE OF bapisditm,
ls_order_items_in TYPE bapisditm,
lt_order_items_inx TYPE TABLE OF bapisditmx,
ls_order_items_inx TYPE bapisditmx,
lt_order_partners TYPE TABLE OF bapiparnr,
ls_order_partners TYPE bapiparnr,
lt_order_schedules_in TYPE TABLE OF bapischdl,
ls_order_schedules_in TYPE bapischdl,
lt_order_schedules_inx TYPE TABLE OF bapischdlx,
ls_order_schedules_inx TYPE bapischdlx,
lt_return TYPE TABLE OF bapiret2,
ls_return TYPE bapiret2.

PARAMETERS: p_file TYPE rlgrap-filename OBLIGATORY.

AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_file.
CALL FUNCTION 'F4_FILENAME'
IMPORTING
file_name = p_file.

START-OF-SELECTION.

lv_file = p_file.

CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload
EXPORTING
filename = lv_file
filetype = 'ASC'
CHANGING
data_tab = lt_lines
EXCEPTIONS
OTHERS = 1.

IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE 'Error uploading file' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

LOOP AT lt_lines INTO lv_line FROM 2.
CLEAR: lt_columns.
SPLIT lv_line AT ',' INTO TABLE lt_columns.

READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 1 INTO DATA(doc_type_raw).
DATA(doc_type) = doc_type_raw.
CONDENSE doc_type.
TRANSLATE doc_type TO UPPER CASE.

IF doc_type IS INITIAL.
MESSAGE 'Missing sales document type in CSV line' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

DATA: lv_dummy TYPE c LENGTH 1.
SELECT SINGLE auart INTO @LV_dummy FROM tvak WHERE auart = @DOC_type.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE |Sales document type { doc_type } is not defined or not active| TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 2 INTO DATA(sales_org).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 3 INTO DATA(distr_chan).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 4 INTO DATA(division).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 5 INTO DATA(itemnum_raw).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 6 INTO DATA(material).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 7 INTO DATA(plant).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 8 INTO DATA(target_qty_raw).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 9 INTO DATA(parnr_numb).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 10 INTO DATA(sched_line_raw).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 11 INTO DATA(req_qty_raw).


DATA: itemnum TYPE bapisditm-itm_number.
itemnum = itemnum_raw.
DATA: target_qty TYPE bapisditm-target_qty.
target_qty = target_qty_raw.
DATA: sched_line TYPE bapischdl-sched_line.
sched_line = sched_line_raw.
DATA: req_qty TYPE bapischdl-req_qty.
req_qty = req_qty_raw.

DATA: ls_dummy TYPE tvakz.
SELECT SINGLE *
INTO @LS_dummy
FROM tvakz
WHERE vkorg = @sales_org
AND vtweg = @distr_chan
AND spart = @division
AND auart = @DOC_type.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE |Sales document type { doc_type } is not assigned to sales area { sales_org }/{ distr_chan }/{ division }| TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.


SELECT SINGLE kunnr INTO @LV_dummy FROM kna1 WHERE kunnr = @parnr_numb.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE |No customer master record exists for customer { parnr_numb }| TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

ls_order_header_in-doc_type = doc_type.
ls_order_header_in-sales_org = sales_org.
ls_order_header_in-distr_chan = distr_chan.
ls_order_header_in-division = division.

ls_order_header_inx-updateflag = 'I'.
ls_order_header_inx-doc_type = 'X'.
ls_order_header_inx-sales_org = 'X'.
ls_order_header_inx-distr_chan = 'X'.
ls_order_header_inx-division = 'X'.

CLEAR ls_order_partners.
ls_order_partners-partn_role = 'AG'.
ls_order_partners-partn_numb = parnr_numb.
APPEND ls_order_partners TO lt_order_partners.

CLEAR ls_order_partners.
ls_order_partners-partn_role = 'WE'.
ls_order_partners-partn_numb = parnr_numb.
APPEND ls_order_partners TO lt_order_partners.

CLEAR: ls_order_items_in, ls_order_items_inx, ls_order_schedules_in, ls_order_schedules_inx.

ls_order_items_in-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_items_in-material = material.
ls_order_items_in-plant = plant.
ls_order_items_in-target_qty = target_qty.
APPEND ls_order_items_in TO lt_order_items_in.

ls_order_items_inx-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_items_inx-updateflag = 'I'.
ls_order_items_inx-material = 'X'.
ls_order_items_inx-plant = 'X'.
ls_order_items_inx-target_qty = 'X'.
APPEND ls_order_items_inx TO lt_order_items_inx.

ls_order_schedules_in-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_schedules_in-sched_line = sched_line.
ls_order_schedules_in-req_qty = req_qty.
APPEND ls_order_schedules_in TO lt_order_schedules_in.

ls_order_schedules_inx-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_schedules_inx-sched_line = sched_line.
ls_order_schedules_inx-updateflag = 'I'.
ls_order_schedules_inx-req_qty = 'X'.
APPEND ls_order_schedules_inx TO lt_order_schedules_inx.
ENDLOOP.

IF ls_order_header_in-doc_type IS NOT INITIAL.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2'
EXPORTING
order_header_in = ls_order_header_in
order_header_inx = ls_order_header_inx
convert = 'X'
IMPORTING
salesdocument = lv_vbeln
TABLES
return = lt_return
order_items_in = lt_order_items_in
order_items_inx = lt_order_items_inx
order_partners = lt_order_partners
order_schedules_in = lt_order_schedules_in
order_schedules_inx = lt_order_schedules_inx.

READ TABLE lt_return INTO ls_return WITH KEY type = 'E'.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_ROLLBACK'.
CL_DEMO_OUTPUT=>DISPLAY( lt_return ).
ELSEIF lv_vbeln IS NOT INITIAL.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT'
EXPORTING
wait = 'X'.
DATA(lt_output) = VALUE stringtab(
( |Sales Order created successfully.| )
( |Sales Order Number: { lv_vbeln }| )
).
CL_DEMO_OUTPUT=>DISPLAY( lt_output ).
ELSE.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_ROLLBACK'.
CL_DEMO_OUTPUT=>DISPLAY( lt_return ).
ENDIF.
ELSE.
MESSAGE 'No valid data to process' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

 

This ABAP report enables bulk creation of SAP Sales Orders by reading data from a CSV file uploaded from the user's local system. It leverages the standard BAPI BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2 to create sales orders in SAP S/4HANA or ECC systems, making it ideal for mass data upload scenarios such as migrations, testing, or initial data loads.

entry.title: Add Indicator Counter on Launchpad Application Tiles
entry.content:
Add Indicator Counter on Launchpad Application Tiles

 

 

 

Introduction
Sometimes you want your Launchpad tile to do more than just open the app ‚Äî you want it to give quick, real-time information at a glance. For example, showing the number of pending requests, open orders, or alerts right on the tile. This is where the indicator counter comes in. In this guide, we‚Äôll walk through how to pull data from your service and display it as a counter on the tile in SAP Launchpad.

Pre-requisite

  • You must have SAP Work Zone (or Launchpad Service) subscribed in your BTP cockpit.
  • Your application should already be deployed and available on the Launchpad.

Steps

  1. Find your entity for counting
    Open your application in the browser, go to Developer Tools ‚Üí Network tab, and click on your service metadata file. This lists all entities available in your OData service.
    • Pick the entity you want to count.
    • Append /$count to its URL to get just the number of records instead of the full dataset.
    • You can also add filters.

  

             

 

          

/odata/v2/trm/TRMHeader/$count

2.Update manifest.json
In your application‚Äôs manifest.json, after the dataSources section under sap.app, add the crossNavigation configuration:

"crossNavigation": {

  "inbounds": {

    "trade_module-display": {

      "semanticObject": "tilecounter",

      "icon": "sap-icon://inspection",

      "action": "display",

      "title": "Tile Counter",

      "subTitle": "No. of Request",

      "signature": {

        "parameters": {},

        "additionalParameters": "allowed"

      },

      "indicatorDataSource": {

        "dataSource": "mainService", // Must match the name of your defined dataSource

        "refresh": 6000,             // Auto-refresh every 6 seconds

        "path": "TRMHeader/$count"   // Path to fetch count data

      }

    }

  }

}
{
  "dataSources": {
    "mainService": {
      "uri": "/odata/v2/trm/",
      "type": "OData",
      "settings": {
        "annotations": [],
        "localUri": "localService/mainService/metadata.xml",
        "odataVersion": "2.0"
      }
    }
  },
  "crossNavigation": {
    "inbounds": {
      "trade_module-display": {
        "semanticObject": "trade_module", // data source should be same  as mentioned at line 03
        "icon": "sap-icon://inspection",
        "action": "display",
        "title": "Tile Counter",
        "subTitle": "No. of Request",
        "signature": {
          "parameters": {},
          "additionalParameters": "allowed"
        },
        "indicatorDataSource": {
          "dataSource": "mainService",
          "refresh": 6000,
          "path": "TRMHeader/$count"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

 

Explanation of each line:

  • crossNavigation ‚Äì Tells Launchpad how this tile should behave and what data to show.
  • inbounds ‚Äì Defines the entry point configuration for your tile.
  • trade_module-display ‚Äì The unique inbound key (can be any meaningful name).
  • semanticObject ‚Äì Used for navigation in Launchpad; should align with your routing setup.
  • action ‚Äì The action to trigger when the tile is clicked.
  • title ‚Äì Main title text of the tile.
  • subTitle ‚Äì Subtitle under the main title.
  • indicatorDataSource ‚Äì This is where the magic happens:
    • dataSource ‚Äì Name of the service defined in dataSources. Must match exactly.
    • refresh ‚Äì How often to fetch new count data (in milliseconds).
    • path ‚Äì OData endpoint for the count. This is what the tile uses to update its counter.
  1. Deploy and Check
    After you‚Äôve updated and saved the manifest, build and redeploy your app. Open the Launchpad and you should now see the counter appearing and updating automatically.

      

            

 

Conclusion
Adding a counter to a Launchpad tile gives users instant insight without having to open the app. It‚Äôs a small change, but it can make navigation more efficient and the overall user experience more intuitive.

entry.title: PO Price Adoption Option in Purchase Requisition (Price get copied from PR to PO)
entry.content:
Configurations to activate PO Price Adoption from PR to PO when creating a PO with reference to PR. 

Step 1: We can check the Purchase Requisition screen in ME51N or ME52N to verify if PO Price Adoption is activated or not.

Step 2: Go to the configuration settings with the path below.
SAP IMG -> Materials Management -> Purchasing -> Purchase Requisition -> Define Configurations based on Purchase Requisition Origin

Step 3: Add New Entry and select which type of procurement (Self-Serve Procurement or Professional Procurement).
Select the right type of procurement below and activate "PO price Adoption". Below, I am selecting the "Professional Procurement" option and save this configuration. 

Then do the same for Self-service procurement in case you need this option too.
Then click back, and here we can see both options as below, and still we can make changes in case we want to select or deselect these options any time in future. 

Step 4: Test the option in the PR screen. 
Run ME51N or ME52N 

Select the right option and check in the PO Price while creating the PO with reference to PR, the system will bring the Price as per the options.
The available options are:
- Do not adopt ‚Äì PO will determine price independently (no carry-over).
- As gross price ‚Äì the gross price (including taxes, etc.) from the PR is adopted in the PO.
- As net price ‚Äì the net price (excluding taxes and other elements) from the PR is adopted in the PO.

Thanks 
Santosh G

entry.title: Converting FSV (Financial Statement Version) into a Flattened Structure using Python
entry.content:
Introduction

The Financial Statement Version (FSV) is one of the most critical structures in SAP for representing how financial data rolls up across accounts and reporting nodes. This article walks through how to use Python within Datasphere Dataflows to flatten the hierarchical FSV structure into a simple, analysis-ready table.

Use case A: Often flattened structures are required by a downstream system (e.g. Onestream, Snowflake or Azure) from SAP Datasphere.

Use case B: Reporting requirements on flattened structure in SAC (SAP Analytics Cloud) stories.   

*Figure : Example of a Financial Statement Version hierarchy with multiple reporting levels.* 

Python Transform

The FSV in SAP stores hierarchical information - each node represents a reporting group, which may have sub-nodes or leaf nodes pointing to G/L accounts.

Source Data:

Using a Python Transform node inside a Datasphere Dataflow, we can achieve this through a recursive traversal. The logic builds two key lookup dictionaries:

  • One mapping each parent node to its children
  • Another mapping each node ID to its node name

Then, a recursive build_paths() function walks through the hierarchy using Depth-First Search (DFS) - visiting each node, building its full path (e.g., Financial Statement Version > Assets > Current Assets), and recording its level details (LEVEL1, LEVEL2, etc.).

# Ensure no missing values in parent IDs
    data["PARENT_ID"] = data["PARENT_ID"].fillna("ROOT")

    # Build lookup dictionary: parent ‚Üí children
    children_map = data.groupby("PARENT_ID")["NODE_ID"].apply(list).to_dict()
    names_map = data.set_index("NODE_ID")["NODE_NAME"].to_dict()

    # Recursive function to build paths
    def build_paths(node, path):
        name = names_map.get(node, "")
        current_path = path + [name] if name else path
        results = [{"NODE_ID": node,
                    "NODE_NAME": name,
                    "FULL_PATH": " > ".join(current_path),
                    "LEVEL1": current_path[0] if len(current_path) > 0 else None,
                    "LEVEL2": current_path[1] if len(current_path) > 1 else None,
                    "LEVEL3": current_path[2] if len(current_path) > 2 else None,
                    "LEVEL4": current_path[3] if len(current_path) > 3 else None,
                    "LEVEL5": current_path[4] if len(current_path) > 4 else None,
                    "LEVEL6": current_path[5] if len(current_path) > 5 else None,
                    "LEVEL7": current_path[6] if len(current_path) > 6 else None,
                    "LEVEL8": current_path[7] if len(current_path) > 7 else None}]
        for child in children_map.get(node, []):
            results.extend(build_paths(child, current_path))
        return results

    # Start from ROOT (or null parent)
    flattened = []
    for root in children_map.get("ROOT", []):
        flattened.extend(build_paths(root, []))

    # Convert back to DataFrame
    data = pd.DataFrame(flattened)

    return data


The final output is a flat table showing node ID, name, full path, and level columns - ready for SAC visualizations or direct joins with GL balances.

 

 

Conclusion 

This approach ensures that the FSV - a cornerstone of SAP Financials remains a powerful, adaptable asset for unified financial reporting and planning.  This method simplifies downstream modelling and Python gives developers precise control over custom FSV structures or hybrid hierarchies that span SAP and non-SAP sources.

 

(To know more about FSV- refer the SAP learning journey)

entry.title: From SAP Datasphere to a Local LLM (Llama 3.1) ‚Äî Hands-On Tutorial
entry.content:
Introduction 

This post documents a small, reproducible pattern for bringing SAP Datasphere data to a local large language model (LLM) for lightweight analysis. The goal is simple: keep modeling and governance in Datasphere, pull a view into a Jupyter notebook with pandas, and let a local LLM produce machine-readable JSON that you can filter, join, or visualize. The prototype runs on a CPU-only laptop so anyone can follow along without special hardware.

What this is:
- A step-by-step walkthrough that uses hdbcli to query a Datasphere view and Transformers to run Meta Llama 3.1 locally.
- A row-by-row prompt pattern that returns compact JSON (total, average, flags) you can plug back into your DataFrame. A row-by-row prompt pattern that returns compact JSON (total, average, flags) you can plug back into your DataFrame.
- A row-by-row prompt pattern that returns compact JSON (total, average, flags) you can plug back into your DataFrame.

What this is not:
- A benchmarking or performance guide. CPU runs are slow but convenient for learning.
- A recommendation to hard-code credentials. The POC mirrors the original notebook for clarity; use environment variables or a vault in real projects.A recommendation to hard-code credentials. The POC mirrors the original notebook for clarity; use environment variables or a vault in real projects.
- A pattern for sending sensitive data to external endpoints. Use test or masked data if you move past local inference. A pattern for sending sensitive data to external endpoints. Use test or masked data if you move past local inference.

What you will build:

A compact flow: SAP Datasphere View -> Python/Jupyter (hdbcli + pandas) -> row-level prompt -> Local LLM (Transformers) -> JSON back to DataFrame. The same prompts can be pointed to managed inference later for production.

Prerequisites

1. SAP Datasphere space with permission to create a Database User and a SQL View
2. Python 3.10+ with Jupyter
3. Libraries: pandas, hdbcli, transformers, torch, accelerate, ipython
4. Hugging Face account + access token (accept access for the Llama 3.1 model)

Security note: The POC code below uses inline credentials to mirror the original run. In real work, put secrets in environment variables or a vault and keep TLS validation enabled.

Part A ‚Äî SAP Datasphere

A1. Enable database access for the space

1. Open SAP Datasphere -> Spaces -> select your space.
2. Go to Database Access and confirm SQL access is enabled for the space 

A2. Create a Database User

1. Database Access -> Database Users -> Create.Database Access -> Database Users -> Create.
2. Grant only read privileges/necessary privileges to the schema/view you will query.
3. Copy the SQL Endpoint (host) and port 443 for Python connectivity. Make sure you copy password and host details and store it in a safe place. 

A3. Create a demo view with a few rows

Create a SQL View (or graphical view). Here we have taken  "ACN_DWC"."DemoView_SETHIR_PY" with columns:
Stud_ID, Stud_Fname, Stud_Lname, Stud_DOB, Maths, Physics, Chemistry, Total, Stud_Addr, Stud_Faname for the demo.
Make sure the view is exposed for Consumption.
Optional seed SQL you can adapt:

SELECT * FROM (
  SELECT 101 AS Stud_ID, 'Arjun'     AS Stud_Fname, 'Singh'    AS Stud_Lname, DATE'2012-04-06' AS Stud_DOB,
         80 AS Maths, 75 AS Physics, 80 AS Chemistry, 235 AS Total, 'Chandigarh' AS Stud_Addr, 'Sukhdev' AS Stud_Faname
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 102, 'Harpreet', 'Kaur',  DATE'2010-09-08', 85, 78, 85, 248, 'Ludhiana',  'Gurinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 103, 'Gursimran','Gill',  DATE'2011-07-09', 95, 85, 90, 270, 'Amritsar',  'Balwinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 104, 'Manpreet', 'Sidhu', DATE'2014-01-01', 90, 85, 95, 270, 'Patiala',   'Harjit'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 105, 'Jasleen',  'Dhillon',DATE'2012-03-02', 89, 90, 75, 254, 'Jalandhar', 'Paramjit'
) AS t;
SELECT * FROM (
  SELECT 101 AS Stud_ID, 'Arjun'     AS Stud_Fname, 'Singh'    AS Stud_Lname, DATE'2012-04-06' AS Stud_DOB,
         80 AS Maths, 75 AS Physics, 80 AS Chemistry, 235 AS Total, 'Chandigarh' AS Stud_Addr, 'Sukhdev' AS Stud_Faname
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 102, 'Harpreet', 'Kaur',  DATE'2010-09-08', 85, 78, 85, 248, 'Ludhiana',  'Gurinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 103, 'Gursimran','Gill',  DATE'2011-07-09', 95, 85, 90, 270, 'Amritsar',  'Balwinder'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 104, 'Manpreet', 'Sidhu', DATE'2014-01-01', 90, 85, 95, 270, 'Patiala',   'Harjit'
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 105, 'Jasleen',  'Dhillon',DATE'2012-03-02', 89, 90, 75, 254, 'Jalandhar', 'Paramjit'
) AS t;

 SAP Datasphere DB user : 
SAP Datasphere DB user screen

Demo View :

Part B ‚Äî Local environment (quick path)

1. Create a project folder and venvCreate a project folder and venv

mkdir datasphere-local-llm && cd datasphere-local-llm
python -m venv .venv
# Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate
# macOS/Linux:
source .venv/bin/activate

2. Install requirements 

pip install hdbcli
pip install sqlalchemy
pip install sqlalchemy-hana
pip install pandas
pip install hdbcli
pip install transformers torch accelerate
pip install ipython

 3. Launch Jupyter

jupyter notebook

Part C ‚Äî Original POC notebook

1. Open a new notebook and write the code.

# --- Imports and setup (original)
import pandas as pd
from hdbcli import dbapi
import warnings
from transformers import pipeline
from IPython.display import display
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

# --- Inline credentials (POC-style; replace with environment variables for real use)
db_user = 'ACN_DWC#SETHIR_DB'
db_password = 'secret'
db_host = 'secret'
db_port = 443
db_schema = 'ACN_DWC'


connection = dbapi.connect(
    address = db_host,
    port = db_port,
    user = db_user,
    password = db_password,
    encrypt = True,
    sslValidCertificate = False   # POC-only convenience; prefer True in real use
)
print("Connected to SAP Datasphere - confirmation")

2. If you see the output - "Connected to SAP Datasphere - confirmation" -- this implies you are on right track.

# --- Query the view
view_name = 'DemoView_SETHIR_PY'
sql_query = f'SELECT * FROM "{db_schema}"."{view_name}"'
print(f"Executing query: {sql_query}")

cursor = connection.cursor()
cursor.execute(sql_query)
rows = cursor.fetchall()
columns = [desc[0] for desc in cursor.description]

df = pd.DataFrame(rows, columns=columns)
display(df.head())

3. At this point, you should see the outcome of the view that you have. The last statement is used for displaying the data in the form of pandas dataFrame.

4. Now we need to prepare our data , so that the LLM can process it. This can be done by converting our data in the form of string format.

# ==============================================================================
#Prepare Data and Interact with OpenLLM
# ==============================================================================

# Convert DataFrame to a string
data_as_string = df.to_string(index=False)
print("\n--- Data Prepared for LLM ---")
print("The DataFrame has been converted to the following string format:")
print(data_as_string[:300] + "\n...")  # snippet preview

5. Prepare data pipeline :

# --- LLM imports
import os
import torch
import json
from transformers import AutoTokenizer, AutoModelForCausalLM, BitsAndBytesConfig, pipeline

# --- LLM Configuration
MODEL_ID = "meta-llama/Meta-Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct"

def load_llama_pipeline():
    """
    Loads the quantized Llama 3 model, tokenizer, and the text-generation pipeline.
    """
    print("\n--- Loading Llama 3 Model ---")
    hf_token = "secret"  # replace with your HF token; accept model access first

    quantization_config = BitsAndBytesConfig(
        load_in_4bit=True,
        bnb_4bit_quant_type="nf4",
        bnb_4bit_compute_dtype=torch.bfloat16
    )

    tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained(MODEL_ID, token=hf_token)
    model = AutoModelForCausalLM.from_pretrained(
        MODEL_ID,
        token=hf_token,
        quantization_config=quantization_config,
        torch_dtype=torch.bfloat16,
        device_map="auto",
    )

    print("Model loaded. Creating text generation pipeline...")
    return pipeline(
        "text-generation",
        model=model,
        tokenizer=tokenizer,
    )

6. Build the prompt for the LLM model :

# --- Prompt builder 
def build_student_analysis_prompt(tokenizer, student_data: pd.Series) -> str:
    """
    Builds a structured prompt for Llama 3 to analyze student marks.
    """
    input_text = (
        f"Student {student_data['Stud_Fname']} {student_data['Stud_Lname']} "
        f"(ID: {student_data['Stud_ID']}) scored {student_data['Maths']} in Maths, "
        f"{student_data['Physics']} in Physics, and {student_data['Chemistry']} in Chemistry."
    )

    messages = [
        {
            "role": "system",
            "content": (
                "You analyze one student's marks and return ONLY a valid JSON object. "
                "Output must start with '{' and end with '}'. No commentary, no markdown, no backticks.\n\n"
                "Schema (keys and types MUST match exactly):\n"
                "{\n"
                '  "total_marks": <int>,\n'
                '  "average_percentage": <float>,\n'
                '  "is_top_performer": <boolean>\n'
                "}\n\n"
                "Rules:\n"
                "1) total_marks = Maths + Physics + Chemistry (each out of 100).\n"
                "2) average_percentage = total_marks / 3.\n"
                "3) Round average_percentage to TWO decimals.\n"
                "4) is_top_performer = true if average_percentage > 80.0; else false.\n"
                "5) Use lowercase true/false for booleans.\n"
                "6) Do not include extra keys. Do not include trailing commas.\n"
                "7) Return JSON only."
            )
        },
        {
            "role": "user",
            "content": input_text
        }
    ]
    return tokenizer.apply_chat_template(messages, tokenize=False, add_generation_prompt=True)

7. Do the analysis : 

# --- Row-by-row analysis
def analyze_student_data(df, text_pipeline):
    """
    Analyzes the student DataFrame row by row using the LLM pipeline.
    """
    print("\n--- Starting Student Performance Analysis with Llama 3 ---")
    results = []
    for index, row in df.iterrows():
        print(f"\nAnalyzing student ID: {row['Stud_ID']}...")

        prompt = build_student_analysis_prompt(text_pipeline.tokenizer, row)

        raw_output = text_pipeline(
            prompt,
            max_new_tokens=128,
            do_sample=False,  # deterministic
            temperature=None,
            top_p=None,
        )[0]['generated_text']

        json_response_str = raw_output[len(prompt):].strip()
        try:
            analysis_result = json.loads(json_response_str)
            results.append(analysis_result)
            print("Analysis successful.")
        except json.JSONDecodeError:
            print(f"  > Failed to decode JSON from model output.")
            print(f"  > Raw model output: {json_response_str}")
            results.append({"error": "Invalid JSON output", "raw_output": json_response_str})

    print("\n--- Analysis Complete ---")
    return pd.DataFrame(results)

# --- Main
if __name__ == "__main__":
    if df is not None and not df.empty:
        try:
            llm_pipeline = load_llama_pipeline()
            analysis_df = analyze_student_data(df, llm_pipeline)

            if analysis_df is not None:
                final_df = pd.concat([df.reset_index(drop=True), analysis_df.reset_index(drop=True)], axis=1)

                print("\n--- Full Data with LLM Analysis ---")
                display(final_df)

                print("\n--- Top Performing Students (Average > 80%) ---")
                top_performers = final_df[final_df['is_top_performer'] == True]

                if not top_performers.empty:
                    display(top_performers[['Stud_ID', 'Stud_Fname', 'Stud_Lname', 'total_marks', 'average_percentage']])
                else:
                    print("No students found with an average greater than 80%.")

        except Exception as e:
            print(f"\nAn unexpected error occurred during the analysis process: {e}")
    else:
        print("\nDataFrame is empty. Cannot proceed with analysis.")

8. Example output (simulated for the final cell)

Full Data with LLM Analysis (excerpt)

Stud_ID  Stud_Fname  Stud_Lname  Maths  Physics  Chemistry  total_marks  average_percentage  is_top_performer
101      Arjun       Singh       80     75       80         235          78.33               false
102      Harpreet    Kaur        85     78       85         248          82.67               true
103      Gursimran   Gill        95     85       90         270          90.00               true
104      Manpreet    Sidhu       90     85       95         270          90.00               true
105      Jasleen     Dhillon     89     90       75         254          84.67               true

Top Performing Students (Average > 80%)

Stud_ID  Stud_Fname  Stud_Lname  total_marks  average_percentage
102      Harpreet    Kaur        248          82.67
103      Gursimran   Gill        270          90.00
104      Manpreet    Sidhu       270          90.00
105      Jasleen     Dhillon     254          84.67

 

Part D ‚Äî Production path (same pattern, managed inference)

When performance or scale matters, swap the local pipeline for a hosted endpoint and keep the Datasphere extraction and prompts identical. When performance or scale matters, swap the local pipeline for a hosted endpoint and keep the Datasphere extraction and prompts identical.

1. Databricks Model Serving / Foundation Model Endpoints (REST).
2. Hugging Face Inference Endpoints (private endpoints; REST with your HF token)
3. SAP AI Core (containerized model hosting; REST)SAP AI Core (containerized model hosting; REST)

Minimal REST skeleton --

import requests, os, json
endpoint = os.getenv("INFERENCE_URL")
token = os.getenv("INFERENCE_TOKEN")
r = requests.post(endpoint, headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {token}"},
                  json={"inputs": "your_prompt_here", "parameters": {"max_new_tokens": 128, "temperature": 0.0}})
print(r.json())



Conclusion ---

This walkthrough demonstrated how to extract data from SAP Datasphere, process it in pandas, and apply a local LLM for row-level analysis that returns clean, machine-readable JSON. The pattern is intentionally small and portable: you can keep iterating locally to refine prompts and outputs, then swap the model call for a managed endpoint (Databricks, Hugging Face, or SAP AI Core) when performance, cost control, or governance call for it. From here, natural next steps include batching larger datasets, persisting results back to a database table, wiring the outputs to SAP Analytics Cloud dashboards, and adding guardrails around data privacy and prompt consistency.

I would be excited to hear how you adapt this to your solutions. Feel free to reach out to me or comment.

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 2
entry.content:
En el mundo de los sistemas de gesti√≥n empresarial, la capacidad de extender y personalizar las soluciones es crucial para adaptarse a las necesidades espec√≠ficas de cada negocio o para proveer ventajas competitivas que le permitan diferenciar su negocio. En el primer blog  de esta serie, exploramos las opciones b√°sicas de extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP (o com√∫nmente llamado SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), incluyendo In-App Extensions y Side-by-Side Extensions.

En esta segunda parte, profundizaremos en algunos de los diversos aceleradores o herramientas disponibles dentro de SAP Cloud ERP, como el ejemplo de la BTP Partner Reference App, Joule for Developers, SAP Build, Multi-Off Delivery y Scalable Delivery. As√≠ que d√©jame llevarte a entender cada una de estas herramientas para potenciar las capacidades de tu compa√±√≠a para crear tu propio IP (Intelectual Property) que es dise√±ado con los principios de clean core lo cual lo hace parte de la estrategia de actualizaci√≥n de la aplicaci√≥n, es decir no se necesitan adaptaciones durante el upgrade.

 

Aceleradores/Herramientas en In-App Extensibility

1. Joule for Developers

Descripci√≥n: Joule for Developers permite a los desarrolladores crear extensiones personalizadas dentro del entorno de SAP Cloud ERP. Proporciona un conjunto de herramientas y plantillas que facilitan el proceso de desarrollo. Esta reciente herramienta combina SAP Build Code, SAP Build Process Automation, SAP Build Apps, y el ABAP environment. Esta hecha para acelerar el desarrollo, mejorar la productividad y traer inteligencia dentro de las herramientas que actualmente usas.

*******NOTA: En este momento Joule for Developers esta disponible de forma gratuita, cuando este periodo termine, el modelo comercial ser√° aplicado, por lo tanto ¬°es el momento perfecto para aprovechar esta oportunidad!.

Requerimiento: Una licencia validad para SAP Build o ABAP

Cu√°ndo usarlo: Ideal para desarrolladores que necesitan crear funcionalidades personalizadas y realizar integraciones complejas dentro de SAP S/4HANA Cloud y usar el poder de la inteligencia artificial para aumentar su productividad al desarrollar c√≥digo.

Ventajas:

  • Herramientas Integradas: Ofrece un conjunto de herramientas y plantillas que simplifican el proceso de desarrollo.
  • Flexibilidad: Permite una mayor personalizaci√≥n y complejidad en las extensiones.

Links Relevantes:

  • Joule for Developers
  • Unlock SAP Joule for Developers - Blog

 

2. Multi-Off Delivery

 

Descripci√≥n: Multi-Off Delivery es una herramienta que permite la entrega de m√∫ltiples extensiones y aplicaciones personalizadas a trav√©s de una √∫nica plataforma. Facilita la gesti√≥n y despliegue de extensiones complejas. B√°sicamente se usa un repositorio y desde ah√≠ la extensi√≥n puede ser distribuida a multiple usuarios

Cu√°ndo usarlo: Ideal para empresas que necesitan gestionar y desplegar m√∫ltiples extensiones y aplicaciones personalizadas de manera eficiente, por ejemplo, compa√±√≠as haciendo rollouts de varias empresas o rollout de varios pa√≠ses donde requieren reusar c√≥digo fuente, o grupo de compa√±√≠as manejando multiples constelaciones de sistemas.

Ventajas:

  • Eficiencia: Simplifica la gesti√≥n y despliegue de m√∫ltiples extensiones.
  • Integraci√≥n: Asegura una integraci√≥n segura y eficiente con SAP Cloud ERP.

Requisitos:

  • One-system Landscape
  • Uso de gCTS 
  • Uso de Namespace

Link Relevante:

  • Multioff Delivery

 

3. Scalable Delivery

Descripci√≥n: Scalable Delivery es una soluci√≥n que proporciona herramientas y metodolog√≠as que permite la entrega escalable de aplicaciones y extensiones personalizadas. Si tienes una soluci√≥n que crees que puede ser usada por cientos de clientes, esta es la opci√≥n adecuada. Es necesario el uso de  SAP Add-on Assembly Kit para desarrollar mejoras espec√≠ficas de la industria, del pa√≠s o de la empresa con SAP est√°ndar y con esto tienes una gesti√≥n completa de ciclo de vida. As√≠ proporcionas add-ons para tus clientes f√°cilmente gestionados, instalados, desplegados y actualizados.

Cu√°ndo usarlo: Ideal para empresas que necesitan asegurar que sus extensiones sean escalables y mantenibles a largo plazo, como por ejemplo socios de SAP que desarrolla aplicativos (add-ons) compatibles que complementan de forma funcional a SAP Cloud ERP los cuales comercializan en el SAP Store.

Ventajas:

  • Escalabilidad: Asegura que las extensiones sean escalables y mantenibles.
  • Metodolog√≠as: Proporciona herramientas y metodolog√≠as para la entrega eficiente de extensiones.

Requisitos:

  • Three-system landscape

 

Link Relevante:

  • Scalable Delivery
  • Partner Extensibility in SAP Cloud ERP: Scalable Delivery with Three-System Landscape | Expert Talk
  • Natively ABAP Cloud (Clean Core) Add-ons in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Aceleradores/Herramientas de Side-by-Side Extensibility

3. SAP Build

Descripci√≥n: SAP Build es una plataforma de desarrollo de aplicaciones sin c√≥digo que permite a los usuarios finales crear aplicaciones personalizadas que se integran con SAP Cloud ERP. Facilita la creaci√≥n de aplicaciones m√≥viles y web sin necesidad de conocimientos t√©cnicos avanzados.

Cu√°ndo usarlo: Ideal para usuarios finales que necesitan crear aplicaciones personalizadas r√°pidamente y sin la necesidad de codificaci√≥n extensiva.

Ventajas:

  • Versatilidad: Permite la creaci√≥n de aplicaciones sin necesidad de conocimientos de programaci√≥n, as√≠ como la opci√≥n de integrar el desarrollo de c√≥digo. 
  • Rapidez: Facilita la creaci√≥n r√°pida de aplicaciones personalizadas.

Link Relevante:

  • SAP Build

 

2. BTP Partner Reference App

Descripci√≥n: BTP Partner Reference App es una herramienta que permite a los partners de SAP crear y desplegar aplicaciones de extensi√≥n directamente en SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform). Estas aplicaciones est√°n dise√±adas para ser compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP Cloud ERP, facilitando la integraci√≥n y el mantenimiento.

Cu√°ndo usarlo: Ideal para quienes desean desarrollar y ofrecer aplicaciones personalizadas que complementen la funcionalidad est√°ndar de SAP Cloud ERP.

Ventajas:

  • Compatibilidad: Asegura que las aplicaciones de extensi√≥n sean compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP.
  • Eficiencia: Facilita el desarrollo y despliegue de aplicaciones de extensi√≥n.

Link Relevante:

  • BTP Partner Reference App

 

Conclusi√≥n

Las opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP son diversas y permiten adaptar la soluci√≥n a las necesidades espec√≠ficas de cada negocio sin comprometer la estabilidad ni la capacidad de actualizaci√≥n (upgrades) del sistema. Desde In-App Extensions para cambios r√°pidos y sencillos, hasta Side-by-Side Extensions para necesidades m√°s complejas, cada tipo de extensi√≥n tiene su prop√≥sito y ventajas. Los aceleradores/herramientas como BTP Partner Reference App, Joule for Developers, SAP Build, Multi-Off Delivery y Scalable Delivery ofrecen herramientas y soluciones que facilitan la extensibilidad y personalizaci√≥n de SAP Cloud ERP.

Espero que esta gu√≠a te haya proporcionado una comprensi√≥n clara de las opciones de extensibilidad disponibles en SAP Cloud ERP, las herramientas y te permita aprovechar al m√°ximo las capacidades de extender esta soluci√≥n. ¬°No dudes en explorar m√°s para descubrir c√≥mo estas herramientas pueden ayudar a tu empresa a alcanzar nuevos niveles de eficiencia y personalizaci√≥n!

 

‚ÄØ

üîéEncuentra toda nuestra oferta‚ÄØ 

En Cloud ERP Product Success ofrecemos un servicio tan vers√°til como nuestro propio producto. Descubre las numerosas ofertas que nuestro equipo ha creado a continuaci√≥n:: 

 

 

S√≠guenos via @SAP and #S4HANA o encu√©ntrame en LinkedIn como @Monica_Pimiento

entry.title: Step-by-step guide to configure customs declaration in S4HANA with GTS
entry.content:
Majority of SAP customers being global players, most of them are engaged in business which requires export, i.e. selling goods from one country to another.

Today, in this blog we will look at the scenario in which manufacturer from Germany is selling goods to a customer in North America.

Configuration Steps:

We need to configure all the steps in the path SPRO >> IMG >> Transportation Management >> Basic Functions >> Global Trade

  1. Customs Activity:
    • Customs Relevance: Here we define an activity which gets updated based on the Customs relevance check (Step-4). This activity will identify whether the freight order should be marked as relevant for Customs Declaration or not. E.g. when the freight order has country Germany as a source and country Spain as a destination, then the checkbox on the freight order will not be marked as relevant for customs and no customs group will be created as per the European Union agreement.
    • Grouping: We provide a process controller strategy (Step-10) which will create groups. Here we are using SAP provided standard strategy EXP_CONS which will create group based on Consignee.
    • Customs Declaration: Here we choose on which status the declaration should be marked as either relevant or not relevant.
    • Process Status: Here we choose what should be the Customs Process status on the freight order like Requested, Approved or Cancelled.
  2. Customs Profile
    • This is a profile which we have to assign to the Freight Order (Step-9).
    • ASR relevant settings: 

      We have to choose certain check boxes based on what should be the pre-requisites for requesting customs declarations and if we want the steps to be performed automatically on change of freight order status.

      • We select first checkbox if we want the loading to be completed before we request customs declaration
      • Second checkbox is dependent on the first one, and is required if we want Customs Invoice (proforma invoice) to be created before we request custom declaration.
      • Third and fourth checkboxes are for automation of the process, like if we want customs invoice to be created automatically when the right status is available. Similarly the last checkbox is if we want the customs declaration to be sent automatically on appropriate status change.
  3. Assign Activity to Profile

    In this step we have to assign the activity to the profile.

  4. Customs Relevancy Check

    Here we define how the customs relevancy check will be performed. Basically, we have to provide the SE24 class along with the method name in which we have logic to identify the customs relevance. Since our scenario is export from EU, SAP has provided ready to use class, in other cases we have to either write our own class and method by using appropriate interface or it is also possible to achieve this thru BAdI.

  5. Customs Status

    Here we define what all customs statuses we want to see on the freight order.

  6. Cumulated Status

    Here we have to define cumulative statuses and associated block reason if we want to block the Freight Order based on those statuses.



  7. Status Assignment

    Here we assign cumulative statuses to the customs status.



  8. Check Customs Statuses

    This is a report which helps us in identifying if any customs status remains unassigned to cumulative status.

    Result of the report looks like this if everything is defined correctly.



  9. Assign Customs Profile to Freight Order

    The customs profile defined in Step-2 must be assigned to the freight order in this integration settings. If this is not assigned, then the customs relevance check is not performed.



  10. Grouping Strategy

    The grouping strategy must be defined in the process controller (Ref. Step-1b).

Now it‚Äôs time to see all these in action.

  1. Create a Sales Order
  2. Plan the freight units associated with the sales order onto a freight order.
  3. Assign carrier, and create delivery. Check customs activity available on the freight order. At this moment, we can see that the customs relevance is not checked.
  4. Set the execution status to ‚ÄúReady for Transport Execution‚Äù. Now we can see that the customs relevance is checked.
  5. Change warehouse execution status to ‚ÄúReady for warehouse processing‚Äù.
  6. Now, we have to perform the relevant steps in EWM like Pick, Pack and mark ready for shipping.
  7. An important configuration on EWM side is required based on business requirements, for when do we want to request customs declaration like before PGI or after PGI. If the highlighted checkbox is marked then we can request customs declaration before performing PGI.
  8. At this point, we can see the customs groups are created, customs invoice is created and customs declaration is sent.
  9. An important configuration is to setup webservice involved in this communication.
    • /SCMTMS/CO_CPX_EXPDECLS_REQ for sending export declaration request from S/4HANA-TM to GTS.
    • /SCMTMS/EXPORTDECLARATIONSUITE is also configured for response message.

  10. Once we receive a response from the Customs Authorities and then from GTS system the freight order is updated with the reference numbers.

The process described above is a basic one. As the custom declaration is a legal requirement, it must be carefully analysed by business and consulting team for the countries involved. As the business grow, the logic may get complex which needs to identify the source/destination and GTS team has to communicate with the right custom office. 

Thanks for reading, appreciate your feedback.

entry.title: AI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completion in SAP Service and Asset Manager
entry.content:
Are your technicians tired of slow, error-prone typing after every maintenance job to feed the data demand of your back office? Our new voice-driven AI turns spoken job details into complete confirmation entries ‚Äì auto-filling hours, expenses, and mileage, hands-free. Cut paperwork, prevent missed information, and help your team close operations faster with cleaner, more reliable data.

In this blog post, we‚Äôll take a closer look at our first productive AI-powered use case implemented for the SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM) mobile app. As my colleague @ZackFrazier outlined in his recent post, ‚ÄúSAP Service and Asset Manager 2505 Now Available ‚Äì What‚Äôs New?‚Äù, we have introduced ‚ÄúAI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completion‚Äù in the latest release, SAP Service and Asset Manager 2505.

Below, we will dive deeper into this AI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completion use case from various aspects: functionality, technology, and commercial considerations.

 

See it in action

Check out this video to understand what this feature entails and how it can support your technicians:


 

What‚Äôs in for you and your technicians?

Let's explore the capabilities and benefits of this feature.

Enhancing Efficiency for Maintenance and Field Technicians

Our inaugural AI-powered feature is designed specifically to boost the efficiency of maintenance and field technicians. It introduces a voice-driven interface that revolutionizes data entry. This cutting-edge feature allows technicians to verbally communicate job details for Work Orders, Service Orders, Operation, or Suboperation directly into the application.

The advanced AI technology then transcribes spoken input into structured data, automatically populating relevant fields such as hours worked, expenses incurred, or mileage traveled. This hands-free approach empowers technicians to capture crucial information promptly and naturally without the inconvenience of manual typing. 

Streamlined Workflow

After the AI accurately fills out the necessary fields, technicians can review and edit the entries if needed. Edits can be made either by verbally re-recording or by selecting and directly updating specific fields using the keyboard. This streamlined workflow accelerates the completion of operations and orders while significantly improving accuracy by minimizing the likelihood of missed or incomplete details.

Boosting Team Efficiency

In essence, this innovative feature contributes to the overall efficiency of the team. By ensuring high-quality data is meticulously maintained, it enhances the team's ability to operate more effectively and efficiently, ultimately leading to a more productive and seamless work environment.

 

How does it work?

Let‚Äôs take a closer look at the technology behind this feature.

Technology Stack and Requirements

The spoken information of technicians are transcribed by native speech-to-text cababilities offered by the standard mobile operating system. Technicians must have an online connection as the unstructured text is sent to the SAP AI Core service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). The large language model gpt 4.1. mini transforms the text into structured data and returns it to SSAM, where it is then entered into the SAP fields on the screen.

To use this new AI feature, you must add the SAP Dynamic Forms service to the entitlements on the BTP subaccount/space where your SAP Service and Asset Manager application is running. However, this prerequisite does not mean you have to use SAP Dynamic Forms actively.

Steps to Set Up the AI Feature

Afterwards you need to go through the following 4 steps:

  • Create the destination required for your mobile application in BTP Mobile Services.
  • Connect the SAP Mobile Service application with SAP Dynamic Forms by configuring the security settings of the SAP Mobile Service application (which links the SAP backend system to the SAP Service and Asset Manager mobile applications). SAP Service and Asset Manager has to be implemented in the same SAP BTP subaccount as SAP Dynamic Forms.
  • Assign users to the role collection which was created by default in step 2 to manage access control.
  • Activate the Application Feature Id ‚ÄúCA_AI_JOB_COMPLETION‚Äù in the ConfigPanel of MAIF (Mobile Application Integration Framework).

 

What‚Äôs the investment to get started?

Regarding commercial aspects, this AI feature follows SAP‚Äôs pricing strategy for AI and falls under the premium AI category. It is a consumption-based model where customers need to acquire AI units and are charged per transaction.

Every completion of an operation or order with AI assistance, regardless of how often the end user re-recorded, will count as one transaction. One transaction is equivalent to 0.05 AI units.

You can use the AI estimator tool to calculate your company's needs for AI units.

As this is an AI feature for SAP Service and Asset Manager mobile app, customers will need an active subscription to SAP Service and Asset Manager to use AI within the mobile application.

 

Conclusion

The AI-Supported Voice-to-Text Job Completion feature in SAP Service and Asset Manager is an exciting addition that will significantly boost the productivity of your technicians and your company. It marks the beginning of transforming how end users interact with our mobile app.

I hope you and your technicians will enjoy this new functionality.

For additional information, visit the Discovery center and our SAP Help Portal.

The application metadata is now available for licensed customers and partners on the SAP Support Portal Software Center. Please ensure to download from there the latest patch release of SAP Service and Asset Manager 2505 version. The mobile client can be downloaded from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.

entry.title: SAP Ariba 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Highlights of Enhancements across Procurement

Accelerated Release Cycle for SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management and SAP Business Network Add-On 1.0 for SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC (BPI-596)

HEADS-UP! Starting with the SAP Ariba 2602 release, the release frequency of the SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management, and SAP Business Network 1.0 AddOn increases to four times a year. This applies to SAP S/4 HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP ECC. The AddOn support package will be released in February, May, August, and November, effective from SAP Ariba release 2602. Increased frequency of delivery provides you with quick access to the latest features, improvements, and compliance enhancements on time, and enables faster adoption.

To benefit from the latest innovations and ensure compliance with support policies, it is recommended that you stay up-to-date by deploying the latest service pack to your production environments.

 

  • This change in release frequency affects the buyer-side add-on, that is SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management and SAP Business Network Buyer Addon, for SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA.
  • This change in release frequency does not affect the supplier-side add-on, that is, SAP Integration Suite, managed gateway for spend management and SAP Business Network 1.0 AddOn for SAP ERP Suppliers.

View implementation details and more here.

 

Enhancements to the SAP Ariba SCIM API (MDATA-596)

This feature introduces the following enhancements to the SAP Ariba SCIM API: Support for new fields for the SAP variant (expenseApprovalLimit and approvalLimit), Support for Generic variant fields (ApprovalLimit, ExpenseApprovalLimit, ShipTo, and PurchasingUnit), Support for the following for both variants: Audit logging of user and group changes initiated by the SCIM API, userType option in the $filter parameter, Group Responsible Purchasing Unit (purchasingUnit) field , New name and description attributes to uniquely identify groups.

View implementation details and more here.

 

SAP Ariba Category Management - Highlights 

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Category Management 2511 Release Key Innovations

 

SAP Ariba Source-to-Contract - Highlights

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Sourcing & Contracts 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview

 

SAP Ariba Procure-to-Order - Highlights

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Procure-to-Order 2511 Release Key Innovations

 

SAP Ariba Supplier Management & Risk - Highlights

For further details on these innovations and more, view our blog: SAP Ariba Supplier Management & Risk 2511 Release Key Innovations Preview

 

 

Stay connected with your community for more insights and updates:

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2511 release- Multi-registration link and for CIM customers- P2P link 
  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
  • What‚Äôs New
